sentence: Financial markets in the U.S., including Nasdaq and New York Stock Exchange, will be closed on Monday, May 28th, in observance of Memorial Day, a time to honor members of our armed forces who gave their lives in the service of our country.

Beyond the parades, cookouts and road trips that will take place during this weekend — which, by the way, marks the unofficial beginning of summer — it is also a good time (for me) to take inventory of the state of the markets, and ponder what’s likely to come in the remaining seven months of the year.
For example, the likelihood (or certainty) of rising interest rates is one of several macroeconomic events investors should be mindful of, or in the spirit of Memorial Day, reflect upon.

In that vein, it would seem that investors’ existing fixation on rising interest rates has jettisoned the once-cliched term “lower for longer,” which has given way to analysts’ constant clamor about “geopolitical risk” when issuing their stock recommendations.
On that note, President Trump’s announcement Thursday that he was canceling the summit meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un likely won’t help assuage said risk.
Still, given my preferred glass-half-full view on things, I’ve chosen to celebrate how resilient the market has been.

All three major indexes enter the holiday weekend in the green on a year-to-date basis, lead by a dominant 7.68% return on the Nasdaq, compared with gains of 0.14% and 1.78% for the Dow and S&P 500, respectively.
Nasdaq has been buoyed by the resurgence in the FAANG stocks — Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Apple (AAPL), Netflix (NFLX) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOG , GOOGL).
The main story this year with the FAANGs, in my opinion, continues to be the smallest name in group (by market cap): Netflix.
The streaming movie powerhouse enters Memorial Day as the best-performing stock in the S&P 500, posting year-to-date gains of 83%.
And with its market cap soaring to $153 billion, Netflix is now the world’s largest pure-play media company by market value, having last week surpassed both Comcast (CMCSA) and Disney (DIS).
And with a Street high price target of $420, suggesting 20% additional gains, Netflix is not done making investors rich.
All of this bullishness, meanwhile, has been supported by strong corporate earnings.
And as I’ve said on more than one occasion, as long as corporate revenue and profits remain positive, as they have been so far this year, equities will continue to charge higher.

So, as you prepare to celebrate our brave men and women who have given their lives so we can enjoy our freedoms, here are four stocks reporting earnings this week to keep an eye on:

Salesforce (CRM) - Reports after the close, Tuesday, May 29

Wall Street expects EPS of 46 cents per share on revenue of $2.94 billion, compared to the year-ago quarter of 28 cents per share on $2.39 billion in revenue.
What to Watch: The cloud computing giant is poised to report not only a top- and bottom-line beat, but also stellar guidance.
About three-quarters of Salesforce’s revenue now come from North America.

The extent to which the company’s can capture more growth overseas will major catalyst for the share price, which aren’t cheap at 60 times forward estimates, compared to a P/E of 18 for the S&P 500 index.

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) - Reports after the close, Tuesday, May 29

Wall Street expects HP to earn 48 cents per share on revenue of $13.57 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earnings came to 40 cents per share on revenue of $12.38 billion.
What to Watch: Is HP finally back?
While the company has delivered sixth straight quarters of revenue growth, investors aren’t willing to forget the suffering they’ve been through due to multiple quarter of declines since 2010.
On Tuesday the company must demonstrate that the uptick in segments such as Personal Systems and Print, which improved last quarter, was not aberration.

Box (BOX) - Reports before the open, Wednesday, May 30

Wall Street expects Box to post a per-share loss of 8 cents on revenue of $139.62 million.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when the loss came to 13 cents per share on revenue of $117.22 million.
What to Watch: Since its IPO, the company has grown revenue at an impressive compound annual rate of 32%.

Thanks to the many strategic partnerships it has in placed with the likes of Microsoft (MSFT), IBM (IBM) and Google, among other giants, Wall Street expects Box to grow earnings at an average rate of 26% over the next five years.
But with will investors be patient and the company invests (spends) to continuously improving and add to its suite of data management products to fight off competitors.

Marvell (MRVL) - Reports after the close, Thursday, May 31

Wall Street expects Marvell to earn 31 cents per share on revenue of $601.01 million.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earnings came came to 24 cents per share on revenue of $579.18 million.
What to Watch: Beyond its strong market position in semiconductors, Marvell has established a growing presence in areas like solid-state drives, where it competes with the likes of Micron (MU).
Its network processing segment, which is much improved, has also helped Marvell emerge as a formidable competitor to the likes of Cisco (CSCO).

But with its shares down more than 3% over the past three months, the company on Thursday must deliver a top- and bottom-line beat and impressive guidance for these fundamental improvements to matter.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
